fields.description:
My 'Branches' folder has completely collapsed. I cannot show/hide content even though I have over a hundred branches in there. 
 
The Branches section used to show all of my local branches. 
 
If I do a search, then matching branches will display and if you clear the filter the list closes again, but this is nowhere close to a solution much less a workaround.
 
If found that if I right-click on Branches section and create a New Branch, then all of my local branches display.  If I delete the "dummy" branch, the Branches section hides itself again without showing the Hide/Show button.  Again, this is not a solution as it's too obscure of a "fix" and requires a dummy branch sitting around.
 
Here is a reference article with other people experiencing the same issue: [https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/SourceTree-sidebar-Branches-folder-no-longer-showing-content/qaq-p/750551]
fields.summary: SourceTree sidebar 'Branches' folder no longer showing content

fields.description:
The link replacement works fine, but it won't open my default browser, instead it open up some embedded browser _inside_ the small commit text window:
https://pasteboard.co/J59vpQ1.png
After I click the RCORE-46 link, it opens the browser at the same small window:
https://pasteboard.co/J59vN71.png
fields.summary: Jira commit replacement link does not open browser

fields.description:
Steps to redo: 
 * Copy any word from here.
 * In Sourcetree, "Actions" menu → "Apply Patch..." → Patch Text
 * Paste in the text box, App crashes. 

tested in 4.0.1

macOS Mojave 10.14.6
fields.summary: App Crashes at pasting anything in "Apply Patch" via "Patch Text"

fields.description:
In Version 4.0.1, multiple SourceTreeLogin seems to get spawn as soon as the app is launched. Each process in turn asks `securityd` to do something. As a result, my `securityd` has a minimum CPU usage of ~20%, sometimes spiking up to 100% without ever going back down.

I'm not sure exactly what Sourcetree is trying do? Ideas?
fields.summary: SourceTreeLogin causes high CPU usage

fields.description: The Mac app needs to be notarized so that Apple can scan it for malicious software and allow the program to open. See the [Apple Developer website|https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/notarizing_macos_software_before_distribution].
fields.summary: Mac App Not Notarized

fields.description:

git --no-optional-locks -c color.branch=false -c color.diff=false -c color.status=false -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree tag -a -m  -f version_released_1.3.20_21 1164795295f4cde523b374bb91e9df094f6a5abd

fields.description: It seems that SRCTREE-3172  has returned with Source Tree 4.0.1 (234) under macOS 10.15.4 (Catalina).  When selecting "Install Command Line Tools" from the SourceTree menu, the error "Failed to install command line tools, please see the system.log for details" is displayed. One difference this time is that nothing is written to any of the system log files when the install fails.
fields.summary: Install Command Line Tools fails on macOS 10.15.4 (Catalina)

fields.description:
Cannot resolve merge conflicts in this version!  (Version 4.0.1 (234))

When I have a merge conflict, I choose Launch External Merge Tool.  The tool DOES NOT launch, but the system reacts as if I launched the merge tool and saved without resolving the conflicts.  My file with the conflicts is now in "pending" instead of in "conflicts", but the conflicts are still there, and Launch External Merge Tool is now grayed out when I try to select it for the file.
fields.summary: External Merge Tool does not launch

fields.description:
I have a parent repo with 3 submodules.

I am using git flow to create branches. In these branches I do a commit to point a submodule to a specific commit. When switching between branches and then double clicking the submodule, in the GUI the commit it's pointed to is not updated. With that said, in the CLI I can see that the commit of the submodule has been update. Also quitting ST and then opening it does get the GUI updated as well..

 

Thank you, Aviad.
fields.summary: submodules don't get updated when parent repo pointer is updated

fields.description: I cannot keep Sourcetree open long on my MacBook Pro (16GB, 4cpu) else it freezes the whole system. I file bug reports to Apple but they're not interested as ST isn't registered with them.
fields.summary: Sourcetree freezes Mac 10.15.4

fields.description:
When viewing the log of a file, you can select "Follow renamed files" to continue viewing the history after it has been renamed.

Unfortunately, if I then try and select any of the commits to the file that happened before the rename, the diff does not show up to the right. It's just blank.
fields.summary: Follow renamed files not showing history

fields.summary: Crash when trying to drag file from working to staging env

fields.description: When using the system appearance mode, in the shutdown state, switch from dark mode to light mode, the appearance does not follow the system switch.
fields.summary: Appearance switching error, 外观切换错误

fields.description:
Sometimes, when I'm reviewing changes before committing, I'll click an image file, and then the before/after view will start taking all of the space. The staged files column disappears completely, as shown on [[this screenshot|https://imgur.com/a/3INzdxz]|https://imgur.com/a/3INzdxz].

Then no matter how large the window becomes, the staged files column will not come back. The only way I've found to restore things to normal is to click the three dots next to the file name, stage the file, and keep staging files until the column reappears, tiny, on the left, and I can resize it to a decent size.

fields.description:
Reproduced on SourceTree v4.0.1 (234)

If a user add multiple Bitbucket login in SourceTree (ST) letting it directly manage such keys, ST is not able to correctly manage key aliases. Therefore it won't be able to automatically pull repositories for the secondary account as it will always default to the default account and SSH keys will fail. 

 

That means: 
 * ST is correctly able to perform OAuth authentication for all account and generate and configure SSH-keys (including {{ssh-add}} and {{.ssh/config}} file). 
 * At this point (after having added the key in your Bitbucket account) projects get correctly get and shown on ST.
 * The moment a git clone is started from the user interface, the clone process fails due to key error. 

The reason for this behavior is that because the project SSH URL has been retrieved via HTTP, it is in the standard format git@bitbucket.org, thus SSH will default to use first SSH credential stored instead of using the Host (e.g. alex-Bitbucket) alias set up by SC during the key generation process. 

 

A possible workaround is to manually substitute the SSH alias so that SSH will start working properly, i.e. will use the correct key. But in doing so, repo link feature in UX will no longer work. And having to replace all URL before a pull is not nice.
fields.summary: Incorrect Management of Multiple SSH Keys Alias

fields.description:
In older versions of SourceTree (or, perhaps, on older versions of MacOS, because I only started seeing this issue after installing SourceTree on a new Mac with OSX Catalina) I could select text from a commit and copy it to the clipboard, then paste it into another app. I would often use this to copy a git SHA I was interested in.

With SourceTree 4.0.1 (234) on MacOS Catalina, however, I can no longer copy selected text. I can select text, but the selection is ignored. Whenever I copy (cmd+c), regardless of what text is selected, what is put into the clipboard is a useless one-line commit summary that contains
 * the first line of the git commit
 * the abbreviated git commit SHA
 * the author and author email
 * the commit date

While this information might be useful to someone, it satisfies only one use case and prevents any other usage of the clipboard. And while the clipboard contains the SHA that is most-often what I am looking for, the SHA is buried amongst a lot of other information that I don't need, which prevents me from pasting the SHA into other tools.

I understand there is a menu item "Copy SHA-1 to Clipboard" that allows me to copy the git SHA for any commit. That is nice, but there is no keyboard shortcut for it which means it is not nearly as useful as the simple, ergonomic, and idiomatic, cmd+c action. Plus, sometimes I want to copy text other than the git SHA - for example sometimes I might want to copy some text from a commit log message. So this menu item exists, but is no substitute for cmd+c.

It is frustrating that SourceTree does not let me copy what I want. It is even more frustrating because SourceTree lets me SELECT text that I want to copy, but then does not copy it - what a cruel mistress you are, SourceTree, to let me think I can copy text like that.

What is the design purpose of preventing users from selecting and copying text? By not allowing cooy/paste, SourceTree is dramatically less useful to me. So please:
 * Restore the copy behavior that copies selected text to the clipboard.
 * If you must, if this is really a dominant use case of the tool, you can copy the one-line commit summary to the clipboard if no other text is selected.
 * And, if you want it to be useful, please add a keyboard shortcut to the "Copy SHA-1 to Clipboard" menu item.

Thanks, and thanks for providing SourceTree to the community.
fields.summary: cannot copy/paste text from SourceTree

If I commit something, it seems as if the app does not correctly update the git status. With this scenario I often get a message that my changes would be overwritten, even though all my files are commited.

2. Open branch B.
3. Make some changes.
4. Commit changes to branch B.
5. Create branch C from branch B.
6. Merge branch A into branch C.

This often ends in a message that the file that I changed at step 3 and committed at step 4 "will be overwritten" by the merge.

Going to the console and calling 'git status' reveals that there are no staged files. And after that 'git status', I can merge my branch with no problems.

Also, I think that if I wait a ew seconds between step 5 and step 6, the issue also does not happen.

So it seems that after a commit, and possibly after creating a branch, the app does not update the git status for a while.

This started happening when I upgraded to SourceTree 4.0.1.

OS: macOS Catalina 10.15.4 Beta (19E224g)
App: SourceTree version 4.0.1 (234)
Git: git version 2.21.1 (Apple Git-122.3)

fields.description:
When I've made changes to files in a project, they appear under the "Unstaged files" heading on the "File status" screen.  Each file appears with a checkbox, status icon, name, and an ellipsis button.  Clicking on the ellipsis button reveals a menu of several items, including "Discard File" and "Remove File".  They appear to mean the same thing, to delete the file from the filesystem, but actually they mean to discard the changes made to the file and delete the file, respectively.

Adding to the confusion, if I open the contextual menu for one of the unstaged files, I get a menu with several options, including "Reset…"  As it turns out, that option does the same thing as the "Discard File" option from the ellipsis menu.

Suggestion: Change both menu options to use the same text.  It should be either "Reset File…" or simply "Reset…", but either way the option should include an ellipsis in its name to indicate that a dialog box will appear when the option is selected, it won't be executed immediately without question.
fields.summary: "Discard file" vs. "Reset…"

fields.description:
I've recently noticed that linting errors are not caught with our pre-commit hooks.

At first I thought it's a problem with *lint-staged* or *husky* but eventually found that SourceTree on Mac just skips the commit hooks.
Committing from the command line or IDE works ok (pre-commit runs).

As the commit window closes quickly, I didn't even know what was the problem.
Only after checking *Preferences > Advanced > Always display full console output*, I saw the following:
{quote}git --no-optional-locks -c color.branch=false -c color.diff=false -c color.status=false -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree commit -q -F /var/folders/vj/md8l7z_52v751h494yhrjr580000gn/T/SourceTreeTemp.B8F4vi

Can't find yarn in PATH: /Applications/Sourcetree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/libexec/git-core:/Applications/Sourcetree.app/Contents/Resources/bin:/Applications/Sourcetree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/bin:/Applications/Sourcetree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/gitflow:/Applications/Sourcetree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/git-lfs:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin

Skipping pre-commit hook

Completed successfully
{quote}
After spending several hours trying to fix it, without luck, I checked with other developers if they have the issue as well, and indeed, they had the same issue.

Observed on different versions of SourceTree and macOS:

SourceTree 3.x on macOS 10.15.1.
SourceTree 4.0.1 on macOS 10.14.6.

Also the PATH error can be other things like:
{quote}Can't find node in PATH
Can't find npx in PATH
{quote}
Basically the issue is that */usr/local/bin* is not in the PATH list.

This is really disheartening (making us doubt the reliability of SourceTree).
Please give this issue priority.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Commit hooks are skipped due to PATH issues

{noformat}
Update README.

Commit: d13fe0e35c59db94c1885817af7167f96565d18b (d13fe0e)

fields.description:
The External Diff tool I use, DiffMerge, won't launch when the action is requested.

Exploration of the contents of my {{.gitconfig}} file identifies the problem.

To reproduce:
 # Install DiffMerge by SourceGear.
 # In SourceTree, configure External Diff to use DiffMerge
 # Open a repository and find a code change.
 # Choose to open in External Diff

Results:

Nothing happens.

Investigate further:
 # View contents of $HOME/.gitconfig file.
 # Observe:

 
{code:java}
[difftool "sourcetree"]
	cmd = /Applications/DiffMerge.app/Contents/MacOS/DiffMerge/Contents/MacOS/DiffMerge --nosplash \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\"
	path =
[mergetool "sourcetree"]
	cmd = /Applications/DiffMerge.app/Contents/MacOS/DiffMerge/Contents/MacOS/DiffMerge --merge --result=\"$MERGED\" \"$LOCAL\" \"$BASE\" \"$REMOTE\"
	trustExitCode = true
{code}
Notice that the paths are wrong to DiffMerge. There is an extra "/Contents/MacOS/DiffMerge" appended to the path. If I manually edit `.gitconfig` to correct the above values, _while SourceTree is running_ to the following value then the functionality is restored:

/Applications/DiffMerge.app/Contents/MacOS/DiffMerge

*But as soon as I relaunch SourceTree*, it rewrites out the wrong configuration.

Affects SourceTree for Mac 4.0.1 as well as 4.0 (4.0.1 is not available in the Affects Version field)
fields.summary: External Diff records wrong path to tool (DiffMerge) and thus doesn't work

fields.description:
Hi,

There is no checkbox or whatever in the preferences to set the force option of the git push command to be `force` or `force-with-lease` (unlike the windows version). So this is ours to figure it out at our own risks.

When pushing to repository, Sourcetree displays the checkbox "Force push". As this is not a git command line, it is impossible to say how the push is forced. Is it with lease or not?

This is critical as code may be lost depending on the end users understanding of that checkbox, as the usual way of force pushing is becoming force-with-lease.
fields.summary: Force push is not the expected push
